elements.content: Three new copper phosphonate coordination polymers have been obtained following very soft synthetic routes, and their structures were determined ab initio from powder X-ray diffraction data. They are based on the two building blocks α,α′-m-xylylenediphosphonic and α,α′-p-xylylenediphosphonic acid, either exclusively or combined with 4,4′-bipyridine as an ancillary ligand. The compound obtained from α,α′-m-xylylenediphosphonate has the formula Cu­(HO3PCH2)2C6H4·3H2O and a 2D structure of mixed organic–inorganic layers built up by the connection of inorganic chains made of edge-sharing copper octahedra via organic bridging groups. The compound obtained from α,α′-m-xylylenediphosphonate and 4,4′-bipyridine as a coligand has the formula Cu­[(HO3PCH2)2C6H4]­[N­(CH)4CC­(CH)4N]·2H2O and a 2D structure based on the connection, via the diphosphonic ligand, of the linear chains resulting from the bridging of copper atoms by the bipyridine moieties. The compound obtained using α,α′-p-xylylenediphosphonate and 4,4′-bipyridine as a coligand has the same formula and a 2D structure closely resembling that of the previous compound. The influence of the factors driving the molecular assembly is discussed, pointing out the crucial role played by the 4,4′-bipyridine in promoting the π–π stacking interactions. With increasing temperatures, the compounds revealed a loss of water molecules bound to copper; in particular, heating the copper α,α′-m-xylylenediphosphonate–bipyridine results in a relatively stable phase with unsaturated coordination sites on the metal atoms. This behavior was confirmed by magnetic susceptibility and electron paramagnetic resonance measurements which also provided evidence for a partial reversibility of the dehydration process and of the occurrence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions between Cu­(II) ions.

The compound obtained from α,α'-m-xylylenediphosphonate has the formula Cu(HO3PCH2)2C6H4⋅3H2O and a 2D structure of mixed organic-inorganic layers built up by the connection of inorganic chains made of edge-sharing copper octahedra via organic bridging groups. The compound obtained from α,α'-m-xylylenediphosphonate and 4,4'-bipyridine as a coligand has the formula Cu[(HO3PCH2)2C6H4][N(CH)4CC(CH)4N]⋅2H2O and a 2D structure based on the connection, via the diphosphonic ligand, of the linear chains resulting from the bridging of copper atoms by the bipyridine moieties. The compound obtained using α,α'-p-xylylenediphosphonate and 4,4'-bipyridine as a coligand has the same formula and a 2D structure closely resembling that of the previous compound. The influence of the factors driving the molecular assembly is discussed, pointing out the crucial role played by the 4,4'-bipyridine in promoting the π-π stacking interactions. With increasing temperatures, the compounds revealed a loss of water molecules bound to copper; in particular, heating the copper α,α'-m-xylylenediphosphonate-bipyridine results in a relatively stable phase with unsaturated coordination sites on the metal atoms. This behavior was confirmed by magnetic susceptibility and electron paramagnetic resonance measurements which also provided evidence for a partial reversibility of the dehydration process and of the occurrence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions between Cu(II) ions.

elements.content: Three new layered coordination polymers based on copper­(II), xylylenediphosphonate, and 4,4′-bipyridine building blocks were synthesized and characterized by means of powder X-ray diffraction and electron paramagnetic resonance techniques. The influence of π−π stacking interactions is discussed, pointing out the role played by 4,4′-bipyridine in driving the building of the crystal structure.
elements.clean_text: Three new layered coordination polymers based on copper(II), xylylenediphosphonate, and 4,4'-bipyridine building blocks were synthesized and characterized by means of powder X-ray diffraction and electron paramagnetic resonance techniques. The influence of π-π stacking interactions is discussed, pointing out the role played by 4,4'-bipyridine in driving the building of the crystal structure.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) are a class of innovative materials widely studied in the past few years for their intriguing properties which make them appealing for a large number of practical applications such as gas storage, heterogeneous catalysis, inclusion chemistry, molecular recognition, nonlinear optics, sensors, and many others. Among the huge variety of chemical compounds belonging to the family of CPs, metal phosphonates (MPs) have been paid less attention compared with materials derived from carboxylate or nitrogenated ligands. This is for several reasons: first, they have a tendency to form dense compounds with extended inorganic connectivity and small surface areas, although some examples of porous materials have been reported; second, they are often highly insoluble, thus precipitating as microcrystalline materials and making their structural characterization a tough challenge; at last, the possibility for phosphonates to act both as mono- or divalent and as mono-, di-, or tridentate ligands makes their coordination chemistry less predictable than that of more studied groups such as carboxylates or nitrogenateds. Anyway, unique features such as high insolubility, easy and soft synthetic routes, and high structural versatility ensure them a spot in materials chemistry.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) are a class of innovative materials widely studied in the past few years for their intriguing properties which make them appealing for a large number of practical applications such as gas storage, heterogeneous catalysis, inclusion chemistry, molecular recognition, nonlinear optics, sensors, and many others. Among the huge variety of chemical compounds belonging to the family of CPs, metal phosphonates (MPs) have been paid less attention compared with materials derived from carboxylate or nitrogenated ligands. This is for several reasons: first, they have a tendency to form dense compounds with extended inorganic connectivity and small surface areas, although some examples of porous materials have been reported; second, they are often highly insoluble, thus precipitating as microcrystalline materials and making their structural characterization a tough challenge; at last, the possibility for phosphonates to act both as mono- or divalent and as mono-, di-, or tridentate ligands makes their coordination chemistry less predictable than that of more studied groups such as carboxylates or nitrogenateds. Anyway, unique features such as high insolubility, easy and soft synthetic routes, and high structural versatility ensure them a spot in materials chemistry.

elements.content: On the basis of our long experience in the chemistry of group IV metal phosphonates, in which the metal atom has essentially a structural function and the global reactivity depends on the organic groups attached to the inorganic framework, we have focused in the recent past on phosphonates containing divalent transition metals belonging to groups VII, VIII, and IX. These can give rise to compounds with physicochemical properties (magnetic exchange interactions, redox properties, presence of coordinatively unsaturated sites, etc.) depending both on the organic ligand properties and on the coordinating metal atom. More recently, we have also taken into consideration the use of phosphonates in combination with other ligands such as carboxylates and nitrogenateds, which are known to show a good affinity for these metals, to expand the possible structural arrangements. Following this research line, we decided to explore the assembly of copper phosphonate building blocks.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of our long experience in the chemistry of group IV metal phosphonates, in which the metal atom has essentially a structural function and the global reactivity depends on the organic groups attached to the inorganic framework, we have focused in the recent past on phosphonates containing divalent transition metals belonging to groups VII, VIII, and IX. These can give rise to compounds with physicochemical properties (magnetic exchange interactions, redox properties, presence of coordinatively unsaturated sites, etc.) depending both on the organic ligand properties and on the coordinating metal atom. More recently, we have also taken into consideration the use of phosphonates in combination with other ligands such as carboxylates and nitrogenateds, which are known to show a good affinity for these metals, to expand the possible structural arrangements. Following this research line, we decided to explore the assembly of copper phosphonate building blocks.

elements.content: The understanding of the relationships between the building blocks and the global crystal structure is indeed a fundamental step in the process aimed to prepare tailor-made materials for specific applications. To achieve this goal, it is crucial to identify the dominant interactions driving the building of the crystal structures.

elements.content: In this work we report the synthesis and structural and magnetic characterization of three new copper phosphonates based on α,α′-m-xylylenediphosphonate and α,α′-p-xylylenediphosphonate, either in combination with 4,4′-bipyridine or alone. 4,4′-Bipyridine turned out to act as the dominant ligand, preventing the formation of an extended inorganic connectivity and yielding 2D compounds characterized by layers with a high organic content.
elements.clean_text: In this work we report the synthesis and structural and magnetic characterization of three new copper phosphonates based on α,α'-m-xylylenediphosphonate and α,α'-p-xylylenediphosphonate, either in combination with 4,4'-bipyridine or alone. 4,4'-Bipyridine turned out to act as the dominant ligand, preventing the formation of an extended inorganic connectivity and yielding 2D compounds characterized by layers with a high organic content.

elements.content: The analysis of the thermal behavior of the compounds revealed that the copper atom is involved in the loss of water molecules when the temperature is raised: each compound showed a peculiar behavior, the most interesting being the mixed copper α,α′-m-xylylenediphosphonate–bipyridine, which upon heating yields a relatively stable phase with unsaturated coordination sites on the metal atoms.
elements.clean_text: The analysis of the thermal behavior of the compounds revealed that the copper atom is involved in the loss of water molecules when the temperature is raised: each compound showed a peculiar behavior, the most interesting being the mixed copper α,α'-m-xylylenediphosphonate-bipyridine, which upon heating yields a relatively stable phase with unsaturated coordination sites on the metal atoms.

elements.content:
All of the chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and were used as received without further purification.

Synthesis of the Phosphonic Acids

The α,α′-m-xylylenediphosphonic acid, (H2O3PCH2)2C6H4 (hereafter 1), was prepared in two steps: First, α,α′-dibromo-m-xylene (5 g, 0.019 mol) was reacted for 1 h and 30 min at 150 °C with triethyl phosphite (6.94 g, 0.042 mol) according to the Michaelis–Arbuzov method. Excess triethyl phosphite was evaporated at 90 °C under vacuum; the tetraethyl ester produced was then dissolved in 35 mL of HCl 6 M and the mixture was refluxed overnight. Then the solvent was evaporated to obtain the desired phosphonic acid, which was washed with a small amount of acetone, filtered under vacuum, and dried. Yield: 67%.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemicals

All of the chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and were used as received without further purification.

Synthesis of the Phosphonic Acids

The α,α'-m-xylylenediphosphonic acid, (H2O3PCH2)2C6H4 (hereafter 1), was prepared in two steps: First, α,α'-dibromo-m-xylene (5 g, 0.019 mol) was reacted for 1 h and 30 min at 150 °C with triethyl phosphite (6.94 g, 0.042 mol) according to the Michaelis-Arbuzov method. Excess triethyl phosphite was evaporated at 90 °C under vacuum; the tetraethyl ester produced was then dissolved in 35 mL of HCl 6 M and the mixture was refluxed overnight. Then the solvent was evaporated to obtain the desired phosphonic acid, which was washed with a small amount of acetone, filtered under vacuum, and dried. Yield: 67%.

elements.content: The α,α′-p-xylylendiphosphonic acid, (H2O3PCH2)2C6H4 (hereafter 2), was prepared following a slightly different procedure: First, α,α′-dibromo-p-xylene (5 g, 0.019 mol) was reacted for 1 h and 30 min at 150 °C with triethyl phosphite (6.94 g, 0.042 mol) according to the Michaelis–Arbuzov method. The reaction mixture was then treated with petroleum ether, and the tetraethyl ester precipitated as a white solid and was filtered under vacuum. The solid was then dissolved in 35 mL of 6 M HCl, and the mixture was refluxed overnight. Then the solvent was evaporated to obtain the final acid. Yield: 94%
elements.clean_text: The α,α'-p-xylylendiphosphonic acid, (H2O3PCH2)2C6H4 (hereafter 2), was prepared following a slightly different procedure: First, α,α'-dibromo-p-xylene (5 g, 0.019 mol) was reacted for 1 h and 30 min at 150 °C with triethyl phosphite (6.94 g, 0.042 mol) according to the Michaelis-Arbuzov method. The reaction mixture was then treated with petroleum ether, and the tetraethyl ester precipitated as a white solid and was filtered under vacuum. The solid was then dissolved in 35 mL of 6 M HCl, and the mixture was refluxed overnight. Then the solvent was evaporated to obtain the final acid. Yield: 94%

elements.content:
The products were characterized by 1H and 31P NMR.

The structural formulas of 1 and 2 are shown in Chart , together with that of 4,4′-bipyridine.

Synthesis of the Cu Derivatives

The copper salt of formula Cu­(HO3PCH2)2C6H4·3H2O (hereafter 3) was prepared by slow evaporation of an aqueous solution (200 mL) of Cu­(CH3COO)2·H2O (0.100 g, 0.5 mmol) and 1 (0.200 g, 0.75 mmol) at a temperature of 60 °C. The starting pH value was 2.2. The light blue precipitate was filtered under vacuum and washed with water. A 0.134 g mass of product was recovered. Yield: 70%, calculated on the basis of Cu. Anal. Calcd for C8H16O9P2Cu: C, 25.16; H, 4.19; P, 16.25; Cu, 16.66. Found: C, 24.97; H, 4.33; P, 15.40; Cu, 15.73.

elements.content:
The stable anhydrous form of 4, hereafter identified as 4a, was obtained by heating 4 at 80 °C for a few minutes.

The copper salt of formula Cu­(HO3PCH2)2C6H4[N­(CH)4CC­(CH)4N]·2H2O (hereafter 5) was obtained by dissolving Cu­(CH3COO)2·H2O (0.100 g, 0.5 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (0.078 g, 0.5 mmol), and 2 (0.133 g, 0.5 mmol) in 200 mL of water at a temperature of 60 °C. The starting pH value was 3.5. A light blue powder precipitated almost instantaneously and was filtered under vacuum and washed with water. A 0.118 g mass of product was recovered. Yield: 45%, calculated on the basis of Cu. Anal. Calcd for C18H22N2O8P2Cu: C, 41.57; H, 4.23; N, 5.39; P, 11.93; Cu, 12.23. Found: C, 41.67; H, 4.10; N, 5.21; P, 11.12; Cu, 11.94.

elements.content: The copper and phosphorus contents of the samples were obtained by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrophotometry using a Varian Liberty Series II instrument working in axial geometry after mineralization of the samples with mixtures of concentrated hydrochloric and nitric acid.
elements.clean_text:
Analytical Procedures

The copper and phosphorus contents of the samples were obtained by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrophotometry using a Varian Liberty Series II instrument working in axial geometry after mineralization of the samples with mixtures of concentrated hydrochloric and nitric acid.

elements.content:
The carbon, nitrogen, and hydrogen contents were determined by elemental analysis using an EA 1108 CHN Fisons instrument.

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns for structure determination and Rietveld refinements were collected with Cu Kα radiation on a PANalytical X’PERT PRO diffractometer and PW3050 goniometer equipped with an X’Celerator detector. The long fine focus (LFF) ceramic tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. To minimize preferential orientations of the microcrystals, the samples were carefully side-loaded onto an aluminum sample holder with an oriented quartz monocrystal underneath.
elements.clean_text:
The carbon, nitrogen, and hydrogen contents were determined by elemental analysis using an EA 1108 CHN Fisons instrument.

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns for structure determination and Rietveld refinements were collected with Cu Kα radiation on a PANalytical X'PERT PRO diffractometer and PW3050 goniometer equipped with an X'Celerator detector. The long fine focus (LFF) ceramic tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. To minimize preferential orientations of the microcrystals, the samples were carefully side-loaded onto an aluminum sample holder with an oriented quartz monocrystal underneath.

elements.content:
Thermogravimetric (TG) measurements were performed using a Netzsch STA490C thermoanalyser under a 20 mL min–1 air flux with a heating rate of 5 °C min–1.

Magnetic properties were measured on powdered samples using a Cryogenic S-600 SQUID magnetometer operating in the temperature range of 2–300 K and with an applied field up to 6.5 T. Data were corrected for the magnetism of the sample holder and for the underlying diamagnetism of the sample evaluated from Pascal’s constant. A temperature-independent paramagnetic contribution χTIP = 60 × 10–6 cm3 mol–1 per Cu ion was also included.

Magnetic properties were measured on powdered samples using a Cryogenic S-600 SQUID magnetometer operating in the temperature range of 2-300 K and with an applied field up to 6.5 T. Data were corrected for the magnetism of the sample holder and for the underlying diamagnetism of the sample evaluated from Pascal's constant. A temperature-independent paramagnetic contribution χTIP = 60 × 10-6 cm3 mol-1 per Cu ion was also included.

elements.content: EPR spectra of 4, 4a, and 5 were recorded at the X-band (9.45 GHz) by using a Bruker Elexsys E500 spectrometer, with a field modulation of 100 kHz and 1 G and a microwave power of 0.02081 mW. Simulations were performed by using the EasySpin Matlab toolbox.
elements.clean_text: EPR spectra of 4, 4a, and 5 were recorded at the X-band (9.45 GHz) by using a Bruker Elexsys E500 spectrometer, with a field modulation of 100 kHz and 1 G and a microwave power of 0.02081 mW. Simulations were performed by using the EasySpin Matlab toolbox.

elements.content: The crystal structures of 3, 4, 4a, and 5 were solved ab initio from PXRD data. Indexing was performed using both the TREOR and the DICVOL06 programs. Space groups were assigned using the Chekcell program. Structural models from powder diffraction data for 3, 4, and 4a were determined using the real space global optimization methods implemented in the FOX program. Trial structures were generated using the “parallel tempering” algorithm. A rough structural model of 5 was obtained using the direct methods implemented in the EXPO program; it was then completed by adding some unidentified light atoms with the aid of the Powdercell program. Rietveld refinements of the structural models were performed using the GSAS program. Crystal data and details of the refinement for 3, 4, 4a, and 5 are reported in Table . Figure shows the final Rietveld and difference plots.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Determination and Refinement for 3, 4, 4a, and 5 

The crystal structures of 3, 4, 4a, and 5 were solved ab initio from PXRD data. Indexing was performed using both the TREOR and the DICVOL06 programs. Space groups were assigned using the Chekcell program. Structural models from powder diffraction data for 3, 4, and 4a were determined using the real space global optimization methods implemented in the FOX program. Trial structures were generated using the "parallel tempering" algorithm. A rough structural model of 5 was obtained using the direct methods implemented in the EXPO program; it was then completed by adding some unidentified light atoms with the aid of the Powdercell program. Rietveld refinements of the structural models were performed using the GSAS program. Crystal data and details of the refinement for 3, 4, 4a, and 5 are reported in Table . Figure  shows the final Rietveld and difference plots.

elements.content: Cheetham et al. proposed a comprehensive classification of hybrid materials including CPs with respect to both the organic connectivity between metal centers and the extended inorganic connectivity. The notation used for this purpose is I n O m , where n indicates the dimensionality of the inorganic connectivity and m indicates the dimensionality of the metal–organic–metal connectivity, with values for n and m ranging from 0 to 3. Obviously, also the value for the sum m + n is limited to 3. Herein we adopt this notation to describe our compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Results

Description of the Structures

Cheetham et al. proposed a comprehensive classification of hybrid materials including CPs with respect to both the organic connectivity between metal centers and the extended inorganic connectivity. The notation used for this purpose is I n O m , where n indicates the dimensionality of the inorganic connectivity and m indicates the dimensionality of the metal-organic-metal connectivity, with values for n and m ranging from 0 to 3. Obviously, also the value for the sum m + n is limited to 3. Herein we adopt this notation to describe our compounds.

elements.content: 3 has a 2D structure in which infinite hybrid organic–inorganic layers (I1O1) lie in the [001] plane, separated by a 9.9 Å distance (Figure ). The copper atom adopts an edge-sharing distorted octahedral coordination geometry in which two equatorial positions are occupied by two crystallographically equivalent oxygen atoms of a bidentate phosphonate group. The remaining equatorial positions are occupied by one water molecule and one oxygen of a monodentate phosphonate group acting as endobidentate ligand: they are placed in the elongated axial positions of the two nearest copper atoms (Cu–O5 = 2.83(1) Å, Cu–Ow2 = 2.83(1) Å). This arrangement results in infinite 1D chains of edge-sharing copper octahedra connected by phosphonate tetrahedra. Adjacent copper atoms constituting one chain are 3.6 Å apart, while the interchain distance, measured between copper atoms, is about 11.7 Å. These chains are linked together via the organic groups bonded to the phosphonate tetrahedra, thus giving rise to the hybrid layers. The interlayer space is occupied by two water molecules which are involved in a network of hydrogen bonds both with adjacent water molecules and with phosphonate groups from adjacent layers. No π–π stacking interactions take place among aromatic rings.

elements.content: Figures and show the structure of 4. This compound also has a 2D structure (I0O2), but it shows remarkable differences compared to 3. Indeed, the layers lie in the [110] plane and are only 7.3 Å apart. The asymmetric unit contains two copper atoms which occupy two special positions with multiplicity 1; both of them assume a distorted octahedral coordination geometry in which two trans equatorial positions are occupied by two equivalent phosphonate oxygen atoms belonging to a monodentate phosphonate group and the other two are filled by two crystallographically equivalent nitrogen atoms from bipyridine ligands. The coordination sphere of the metal ions is completed by two water molecules in the elongated axial positions that point toward the interlayer region (Cu1–Ow1 = 2.50(1) Å, Cu2–Ow2 = 2.54(1) Å). The layers are made of infinite rows built by bipyridine ligands acting as bridging groups between two nonequivalent copper atoms and connected by phosphonate molecules bonded to two nonequivalent copper atoms. At variance with 3, the phenyl ring of phosphonate molecules is sandwiched between two bipyridine ligands, so that groups of three π–π stacked rings can be recognized. Finally, the free oxygen atoms of phosphonate groups are involved in intralayer hydrogen bonds with both coordinating water molecules and free oxygen atoms of phosphonate groups. Interlayer hydrogen bonds are also present between water molecules and free phosphonate oxygen atoms.

elements.content: 4 undergoes a phase transition when heated at 80 °C, switching its color from blue to purple, yielding the compound named 4a, which is stable for several days if left standing in moist air. Analysis of the structure (a layer of which is shown in Figure ) indicates that this phase transition only involves the loss of water molecules previously bonded to the metal atom, without influencing the organic part of the structure. This makes the axial positions of both the octahedral copper free, but the two metal atoms undergo different processes: one of them retains a distorted octahedral geometry, since the vacancies in its coordination sphere are filled by two oxygen atoms belonging to a chelating bidentate phosphonate group, while the other one becomes square planar. This variation in the coordination geometry is confirmed by EPR measurements that will be discussed later. Interestingly, the transition is fully reversible if anhydrous 4a is kept for a few minutes in water at 80 °C.

elements.content: 5 has a 2D structure (I0O2) resembling the structure of 4, although the symmetry is monoclinic and not triclinic (Figure ). The layers lie in the [002] plane and are 5.7 Å apart. The asymmetric unit contains one copper atom with a distorted octahedral geometry: the equatorial plane is occupied by two oxygen atoms belonging to two phosphonate groups and two nonequivalent nitrogen atoms belonging to the bipyridine moiety, while two water molecules occupy the elongated axial positions (Cu–Ow1 = 2.32(3) Å, Cu–Ow2 = 2.57(3) Å). The layer structure is similar to that of 4, being constituted of infinite rows built from Cu atoms connected by the bipyridine molecules in one dimension and by the phosphonate molecules in the other one. The main difference compared to 4 is in the π–π stacking interactions: infinite arrays of stacked aromatic rings can be recognized, involving both the phenyl rings of the phosphonate and one of the rings of bipyridine; as a consequence, every bipyridine unit has a nonstacked ring held between two PO3C tetrahedra. The free oxygen atoms of the phosphonate groups are involved in intralayer hydrogen bonds both with water molecules coordinating copper and with opposite free phosphonate oxygen atoms, as seen for 4. Hydrogen bonds between coordinating oxygen atoms and water molecules from adjacent layers are also present.

elements.content: 3 shows a first step of weight loss of 12.95%, occurring around 100 °C, which can be assigned to the loss of the three water molecules (calcd 14.15%). The PXRD pattern of this high-temperature phase was indexed with the following triclinic unit cell: a = 6.859(8) Å, b = 8.279(7) Å, c = 21.57(2) Å, α = 84.4(1)°, β = 85.6(2)°, γ = 68.59(5)° (M(20) = 10). The transition is spontaneously reversible, and the compound cooled to room temperature returns to its original crystalline form. After 100 °C the decomposition of the material continues with a series of unresolved steps (Figures S and S, ).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior

 3 shows a first step of weight loss of 12.95%, occurring around 100 °C, which can be assigned to the loss of the three water molecules (calcd 14.15%). The PXRD pattern of this high-temperature phase was indexed with the following triclinic unit cell: a = 6.859(8) Å, b = 8.279(7) Å, c = 21.57(2) Å, α = 84.4(1)°, β = 85.6(2)°, γ = 68.59(5)° (M(20) = 10). The transition is spontaneously reversible, and the compound cooled to room temperature returns to its original crystalline form. After 100 °C the decomposition of the material continues with a series of unresolved steps (Figures S and S, ).

elements.content: 4 also shows a weight loss around 100 °C which is due to the loss of the two water molecules (calcd 6.92%, found 6.05%), yielding 4a. This phase is stable up to 300 °C, when decomposition of the organic part occurs (Figure S, ).
elements.clean_text: 4 also shows a weight loss around 100 °C which is due to the loss of the two water molecules (calcd 6.92%, found 6.05%), yielding 4a. This phase is stable up to 300 °C, when decomposition of the organic part occurs (Figure S, ).

elements.content: 5 shows a weight loss around 100 °C due to the loss of two water molecules (calcd 6.92%, found 6.75%). Also this compound changes color from light blue to purple when heated, but the phase formed after the loss of water molecules is not as crystalline as the starting material; if the sample is cooled, it turns back to its initial color, but the PXRD pattern is different from those of both the initial material and the heated one, indicating that the transition is not reversible and permanent modifications in the structure are caused by the loss of the water molecules. The material is stable up to 300 °C, when decomposition of the organic part occurs (Figure S and S, ).

The material is stable up to 300 °C, when decomposition of the organic part occurs (Figure S and S, ).

elements.content: Figure shows the FT-IR spectra of 3, 4, 4a, and 5. There are some common features present in every spectrum: the C–H stretching vibrations are visible between 2800 and 3150 cm–1; the broad bands between 2500 and 3000 cm–1 and 2000 and 2500 cm–1 can be assigned to the P–OH stretching, and the same is true for the broad band around 1670 cm–1, especially visible in 3, which arises when a PO bond is also present in the compound.
elements.clean_text:
FT-IR Spectra

Figure  shows the FT-IR spectra of 3, 4, 4a, and 5. There are some common features present in every spectrum: the C-H stretching vibrations are visible between 2800 and 3150 cm-1; the broad bands between 2500 and 3000 cm-1 and 2000 and 2500 cm-1 can be assigned to the P-OH stretching, and the same is true for the broad band around 1670 cm-1, especially visible in 3, which arises when a PO bond is also present in the compound.

elements.content: FT-IR spectra of 3 (a), 4 (b), 4a (c), and 5 (d).
elements.clean_text: 7  FT-IR spectra of 3 (a), 4 (b), 4a (c), and 5 (d).

elements.content: The O–H stretching vibrations of water fall in the region between 3000 and 3700 cm–1, where 3, 4, and 5 show peculiar features, in agreement with the different hydrogen-bonding interactions present in each of them. 4a shows no bands in this region due to the lack of water inside its structure.
elements.clean_text: The O-H stretching vibrations of water fall in the region between 3000 and 3700 cm-1, where 3, 4, and 5 show peculiar features, in agreement with the different hydrogen-bonding interactions present in each of them. 4a shows no bands in this region due to the lack of water inside its structure.

elements.content: Between 1300 and 1600 cm–1, bands due to the aromatic C–C and C–N stretching and those related to the aromatic C–H bending are found; the bands at 1540 and 1322 cm–1, only present in the bipyridine-containing compounds, can be assigned to the C–N bonds.
elements.clean_text: Between 1300 and 1600 cm-1, bands due to the aromatic C-C and C-N stretching and those related to the aromatic C-H bending are found; the bands at 1540 and 1322 cm-1, only present in the bipyridine-containing compounds, can be assigned to the C-N bonds.

elements.content: The P–O stretching modes give rise to the system of strong bands between 900 and 1200 cm–1: 4 and 5 show very similar features in this region, in agreement with the analogous connectivity of the phosphonates in the two compounds.

elements.content:
X-band EPR measurements were performed on 4, 4a, and 5 at room temperature.

For none of the reported spectra is a hyperfine structure observed, indicating that the magnetic exchange between the centers is stronger than the hyperfine interaction.

5 shows an axial spectrum with g ∥ ≈ 2.35 and g ⊥ ≈ 2.08 (Figure ), typical of a copper center with an elongated octahedral coordination geometry, consistent with the PXRD data. After the sample is heated, a different room temperature EPR spectrum is observed, with g ∥ ≈ 2.29 and g ⊥ ≈ 2.06, in agreement with the structural transformation suggested by PXRD analysis. Finally, after two days, the g values get closer to the original ones, g ∥ ≈ 2.34 and g ⊥ ≈ 2.07, but are still different, suggesting a slow recovery of the pristine structure.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic and EPR Characterization

X-band EPR measurements were performed on 4, 4a, and 5 at room temperature.

For none of the reported spectra is a hyperfine structure observed, indicating that the magnetic exchange between the centers is stronger than the hyperfine interaction.

 5 shows an axial spectrum with g ∥ ~ 2.35 and g ⊥ ~ 2.08 (Figure ), typical of a copper center with an elongated octahedral coordination geometry, consistent with the PXRD data. After the sample is heated, a different room temperature EPR spectrum is observed, with g ∥ ~ 2.29 and g ⊥ ~ 2.06, in agreement with the structural transformation suggested by PXRD analysis. Finally, after two days, the g values get closer to the original ones, g ∥ ~ 2.34 and g ⊥ ~ 2.07, but are still different, suggesting a slow recovery of the pristine structure.

elements.content: EPR spectra of 5 as prepared (black line), after being heated at 130 °C for 30 min and kept in a dry atmosphere at 300 K (red line), and after 2 days of air exposition (blue line). All the spectra were registered at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 8  EPR spectra of 5 as prepared (black line), after being heated at 130 °C for 30 min and kept in a dry atmosphere at 300 K (red line), and after 2 days of air exposition (blue line). All the spectra were registered at room temperature.

elements.content: A rhombic EPR spectrum is observed for 4, with g 1 = 2.28, g 2 = 2.12, and g 3 = 2.06 (Figure ). In this compound (Figure ), the coordination geometry of each of the two nonequivalent copper centers in the asymmetric unit is similar to that of the Cu center in 5. However, the coordination octahedra of these two centers are not parallel to each other. The observed rhombic spectrum is therefore attributed to the result of the average of the g tensors of the two centers due to the exchange interaction.

elements.content: An analogous explanation can be given for the rhombic spectrum of 4a (Figure ), where the exchange interaction averages the contributions of the two axial spectra of the planar and octahedral copper centers. However, the g values observed in this case (g 1 = 2.20, g 2 = 2.11, g 3 = 2.05) are markedly different from those of 4, confirming the structural changes in the copper coordination following the dehydration process. Interestingly, if the EPR measurement on 4a is repeated after a few days, a less intense feature (ca. 15% of the global spectral intensity) with the same g values observed in 4 is superposed onto the spectrum reported in Figure , indicating a partial rehydration of the sample (Figure S, ).

elements.content: Following the evidence of non-negligible exchange interactions between Cu centers obtained by EPR spectroscopy, the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of the four samples was also investigated. At room temperature χT is 0.43, 0.43, 0.42, and 0.45 cm3 K mol–1 for 3, 4, 4a, and 5, respectively. The values are those expected for independent copper­(II) ions and agree well with the average g values obtained from EPR spectra.
elements.clean_text: Following the evidence of non-negligible exchange interactions between Cu centers obtained by EPR spectroscopy, the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of the four samples was also investigated. At room temperature χT is 0.43, 0.43, 0.42, and 0.45 cm3 K mol-1 for 3, 4, 4a, and 5, respectively. The values are those expected for independent copper(II) ions and agree well with the average g values obtained from EPR spectra.

elements.content: Weak antiferromagnetic spin interactions are observed for the samples with an almost planar magnetic structure, i.e., 4, 4a, and 5, the Θ values obtained from the Curie–Weiss fits being ca. −1 K, in good agreement with the existing exchange pathways. Albeit small, the magnitude of the exchange interaction, J, is large enough to produce an averaging of the g tensor, as witnessed by EPR spectroscopy; i.e. J > Δgμ0βH, where Δg is the difference in the g components of the two centers being averaged, β is the Bohr magneton, and μ0 H is the magnetic field.

Albeit small, the magnitude of the exchange interaction, J, is large enough to produce an averaging of the g tensor, as witnessed by EPR spectroscopy; i.e. J > Δgμ0βH, where Δg is the difference in the g components of the two centers being averaged, β is the Bohr magneton, and μ0 H is the magnetic field.

elements.content: For 3 weak intrachain antiferromagnetic interactions mediated by the O–P–O bridge interacting with the d x 2–y 2 magnetic orbitals of the copper are indicated by the low temperature decrease of the χT product. Below 5 K an interchain ferromagnetic spin interaction produces a weak increase of the χT product.

elements.content: The different geometrical arrangements and symmetries of 1 and 2 dramatically influence the crystal structure of the corresponding copper derivatives. A copper α,α′-p-xylylenediphosphonate (Cu–pXDP) was synthesized by Férey and co-workers with a pillar-layered structure (I2O1) based on the Cu­(O3PCH3)·H2O archetype prepared by Zhang and Clearfield, where clusters of two square pyramidal copper atoms sharing one edge are connected in two dimensions by PO3C tetrahedra belonging to pillaring diphosphonates (Figure ). 3 adopts a completely different structure, with mixed inorganic–organic layers and a one-dimension extended inorganic connectivity. The P/Cu ratio in 3 is 2, whereas it is 1 in Cu–pXDP, for which the coordination geometry of copper is also different, being square pyramidal compared to the distorted octahedral in 3.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The different geometrical arrangements and symmetries of 1 and 2 dramatically influence the crystal structure of the corresponding copper derivatives. A copper α,α'-p-xylylenediphosphonate (Cu-pXDP) was synthesized by Férey and co-workers with a pillar-layered structure (I2O1) based on the Cu(O3PCH3)⋅H2O archetype prepared by Zhang and Clearfield, where clusters of two square pyramidal copper atoms sharing one edge are connected in two dimensions by PO3C tetrahedra belonging to pillaring diphosphonates (Figure ). 3 adopts a completely different structure, with mixed inorganic-organic layers and a one-dimension extended inorganic connectivity. The P/Cu ratio in 3 is 2, whereas it is 1 in Cu-pXDP, for which the coordination geometry of copper is also different, being square pyramidal compared to the distorted octahedral in 3.

elements.content: View of the structure of Cu–pXDP along the c axis.
elements.clean_text: 11  View of the structure of Cu-pXDP along the c axis.

elements.content: The presence of 4,4′-bipyridine in 4 and 5 induces several effects: acting as a bridging ligand, it takes the copper atoms apart from each other, breaking both the two-atom clusters in Cu–pXDP and the chain structure in 3; it is also responsible for the presence of π–π stacking interactions that turn out to play a dominant role in the building of the crystal structures. As a consequence, the structures of 4 and 5 resemble each other much more than those of 3 and Cu–pXDP. The connectivities of copper atoms in 4 and 5 are identical: the two structures differ basically for the way the π–π stacking interactions are arranged, as a consequence of the different geometrical and symmetrical features of 1 and 2. In 4, the interactions involve three aromatic rings at a time, and all of the aromatic rings are engaged in this net of localized π–π stacking, whereas in 5 the interactions are extended in one direction, but involve two-thirds of the aromatic rings present in the structure.
elements.clean_text: The presence of 4,4'-bipyridine in 4 and 5 induces several effects: acting as a bridging ligand, it takes the copper atoms apart from each other, breaking both the two-atom clusters in Cu-pXDP and the chain structure in 3; it is also responsible for the presence of π-π stacking interactions that turn out to play a dominant role in the building of the crystal structures. As a consequence, the structures of 4 and 5 resemble each other much more than those of 3 and Cu-pXDP. The connectivities of copper atoms in 4 and 5 are identical: the two structures differ basically for the way the π-π stacking interactions are arranged, as a consequence of the different geometrical and symmetrical features of 1 and 2. In 4, the interactions involve three aromatic rings at a time, and all of the aromatic rings are engaged in this net of localized π-π stacking, whereas in 5 the interactions are extended in one direction, but involve two-thirds of the aromatic rings present in the structure.

elements.content: Notably, 5 has a structural arrangement similar to that of a recently synthesized copper derivative based on a P,P′-diphenyl-p-xylylenediphosphinate and 4,4′-bipyridine, in which a phenyl ring is bonded to the phosphorus atom in place of an −OH group. As a consequence, this compound showed π–π stacking interactions between two aromatic rings of adjacent diphosphinate molecules, instead of the hydrogen bonds between opposite −OH groups observed in 5. In this arrangement, three-fifths of the aromatic rings are engaged in the network of π–π stacking interactions.
elements.clean_text: Notably, 5 has a structural arrangement similar to that of a recently synthesized copper derivative based on a P,P'-diphenyl-p-xylylenediphosphinate and 4,4'-bipyridine, in which a phenyl ring is bonded to the phosphorus atom in place of an -OH group. As a consequence, this compound showed π-π stacking interactions between two aromatic rings of adjacent diphosphinate molecules, instead of the hydrogen bonds between opposite -OH groups observed in 5. In this arrangement, three-fifths of the aromatic rings are engaged in the network of π-π stacking interactions.

elements.content:
Figure reports the comparison of the structures of 3, 4, 5, and the compound of ref , highlighting the analogies discussed above.

The effect of π–π stacking could also be invoked to justify the different behaviors of the phosphonates in the phase transition of 4 into 4a (Figure ): In 4, both of them have their free oxygen atoms involved in the same number of hydrogen bonds, so that they could be considered chemically equivalent. On this basis, they could be expected to behave the same way once the water molecules are lost and act as bidentate chelating ligands in 4a. However, since the structure seems to be subject to the control of π–π stacking, we can hypothesize that the chelation of both the metal atoms could be forbidden for steric reasons: this process could force the diphosphonic moiety to undergo a distortion which could interfere with the ordered arrangement required by the stacking, so that only one phosphonic group for each molecule is free to act as a chelating ligand. The behavior observed when heating 5 suggests that something similar to what is described above could happen also in this compound, but for some reason that we cannot explain, there is no full reversibility in the process.

The behavior observed when heating 5 suggests that something similar to what is described above could happen also in this compound, but for some reason that we cannot explain, there is no full reversibility in the process.

elements.content: Notably, all of the reported compounds show a remarkable stability, being unsoluble even in boiling water, a feature that is not trivial when dealing with divalent metal coordination polymers: this behavior can be ascribed to the presence of phosphonic building blocks, which are known to yield more robust materials compared with other organic ligands.
elements.clean_text: Notably, all of the reported compounds show a remarkable stability, being unsoluble even in boiling water, a feature that is not trivial when dealing with divalent metal coordination polymers: this behavior can be ascribed to the presence of phosphonic building blocks, which are known to yield more robust materials compared with other organic ligands.

elements.content: Three new layered copper phosphonates were synthesized, and their structures were solved ab initio from PXRD data. The structure of the anhydrous form of 4 (4a) was also solved, revealing the presence of relatively stable coordination vacancies on the metal atom resulting from the loss of water ligands at 80 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three new layered copper phosphonates were synthesized, and their structures were solved ab initio from PXRD data. The structure of the anhydrous form of 4 (4a) was also solved, revealing the presence of relatively stable coordination vacancies on the metal atom resulting from the loss of water ligands at 80 °C.

elements.content: From a crystallographic point of view, the role of 4,4′-bipyridine in the building of the crystal structures was pointed out, revealing that the main structure driving factor is the π–π stacking interaction, responsible for the similarity between the structures of 4 and 5.
elements.clean_text: From a crystallographic point of view, the role of 4,4'-bipyridine in the building of the crystal structures was pointed out, revealing that the main structure driving factor is the π-π stacking interaction, responsible for the similarity between the structures of 4 and 5.

elements.content: Magnetic and EPR characterization of 4 and 5 were consistent with the coordination environment deduced by PXRD data and suggested only weak antiferromagnetic interactions to be active among metal centers. These are, however, large enough to produce an averaging of the g values of the adjacent copper centers in 4a, thus resulting in rhombic spectra for a system with two nonequivalent metal ions. This confirmed the structural modification induced by the thermal treatment of the samples and further suggested that the process is only partially reversible.
elements.clean_text: Magnetic and EPR characterization of 4 and 5 were consistent with the coordination environment deduced by PXRD data and suggested only weak antiferromagnetic interactions to be active among metal centers. These are, however, large enough to produce an averaging of the g values of the adjacent copper centers in 4a, thus resulting in rhombic spectra for a system with two nonequivalent metal ions. This confirmed the structural modification induced by the thermal treatment of the samples and further suggested that the process is only partially reversible.

elements.content: The systems investigated in this work have been shown to prefer closely packed structures. It may be of interest to try to reduce the influence of π–π stacking interactions, for example, by using aliphatic phosphonates in combination with 4,4′-bipyridine, to obtain more flexible and open framework structures.
elements.clean_text: The systems investigated in this work have been shown to prefer closely packed structures. It may be of interest to try to reduce the influence of π-π stacking interactions, for example, by using aliphatic phosphonates in combination with 4,4'-bipyridine, to obtain more flexible and open framework structures.

elements.content: 1H and 31P NMR data for 1 and 2, detailed procedures for structure determination and refinement, crystallographic information file (CIF) for 3, 4, 4a, and 5, tables with complete crystallographic parameters for 3, 4, 4a, and 5, additional figures for 4 and 5, TG curves for 3, 4, and 5, high-temperature PXRD patterns for 3 and 5, magnetic measurements for 3, 4, 4a, and 5, and EPR spectrum of 4a a few days after the dehydration process. cln_elements.content:
All of the chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and were used as received without further purification.

Synthesis of the Phosphonic Acids

The α,α′-m-xylylenediphosphonic acid, (H2O3PCH2)2C6H4 (hereafter 1), was prepared in two steps: First, α,α′-dibromo-m-xylene (5 g, 0.019 mol) was reacted for 1 h and 30 min at 150 °C with triethyl phosphite (6.94 g, 0.042 mol) according to the Michaelis–Arbuzov method. Excess triethyl phosphite was evaporated at 90 °C under vacuum; the tetraethyl ester produced was then dissolved in 35 mL of HCl 6 M and the mixture was refluxed overnight. Then the solvent was evaporated to obtain the desired phosphonic acid, which was washed with a small amount of acetone, filtered under vacuum, and dried. Yield: 67%.

The α,α′-p-xylylendiphosphonic acid, (H2O3PCH2)2C6H4 (hereafter 2), was prepared following a slightly different procedure: First, α,α′-dibromo-p-xylene (5 g, 0.019 mol) was reacted for 1 h and 30 min at 150 °C with triethyl phosphite (6.94 g, 0.042 mol) according to the Michaelis–Arbuzov method. The reaction mixture was then treated with petroleum ether, and the tetraethyl ester precipitated as a white solid and was filtered under vacuum. The solid was then dissolved in 35 mL of 6 M HCl, and the mixture was refluxed overnight. Then the solvent was evaporated to obtain the final acid. Yield: 94%

The products were characterized by 1H and 31P NMR.

The structural formulas of 1 and 2 are shown in Chart , together with that of 4,4′-bipyridine.

Synthesis of the Cu Derivatives

The copper salt of formula Cu­(HO3PCH2)2C6H4·3H2O (hereafter 3) was prepared by slow evaporation of an aqueous solution (200 mL) of Cu­(CH3COO)2·H2O (0.100 g, 0.5 mmol) and 1 (0.200 g, 0.75 mmol) at a temperature of 60 °C. The starting pH value was 2.2. The light blue precipitate was filtered under vacuum and washed with water. A 0.134 g mass of product was recovered. Yield: 70%, calculated on the basis of Cu. Anal. Calcd for C8H16O9P2Cu: C, 25.16; H, 4.19; P, 16.25; Cu, 16.66. Found: C, 24.97; H, 4.33; P, 15.40; Cu, 15.73.

The copper salt of formula Cu­(HO3PCH2)2C6H4[N­(CH)4CC­(CH)4N]·2H2O (hereafter 4) was prepared by slow evaporation of an aqueous solution (200 mL) of Cu­(CH3COO)2·H2O (0.100 g, 0.5 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (0.078 g, 0.5 mmol), and 1 (0.133 g, 0.5 mmol) at a temperature of 60 °C. The starting pH value was 3.3. The obtained tiny blue crystals were filtered under vacuum and washed with water. A 0.183 g mass of product was recovered. Yield: 70%, calculated on the basis of Cu. Anal. Calcd for C18H22N2O8P2Cu: C, 41.57; H, 4.23; N, 5.39; P, 11.93; Cu, 12.23. Found: C, 40.83; H, 4.13; N, 5.11; P, 11.33; Cu, 13.05.

The stable anhydrous form of 4, hereafter identified as 4a, was obtained by heating 4 at 80 °C for a few minutes.

The copper salt of formula Cu­(HO3PCH2)2C6H4[N­(CH)4CC­(CH)4N]·2H2O (hereafter 5) was obtained by dissolving Cu­(CH3COO)2·H2O (0.100 g, 0.5 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (0.078 g, 0.5 mmol), and 2 (0.133 g, 0.5 mmol) in 200 mL of water at a temperature of 60 °C. The starting pH value was 3.5. A light blue powder precipitated almost instantaneously and was filtered under vacuum and washed with water. A 0.118 g mass of product was recovered. Yield: 45%, calculated on the basis of Cu. Anal. Calcd for C18H22N2O8P2Cu: C, 41.57; H, 4.23; N, 5.39; P, 11.93; Cu, 12.23. Found: C, 41.67; H, 4.10; N, 5.21; P, 11.12; Cu, 11.94.

cln_elements.content:
3 shows a first step of weight loss of 12.95%, occurring around 100 °C, which can be assigned to the loss of the three water molecules (calcd 14.15%). The PXRD pattern of this high-temperature phase was indexed with the following triclinic unit cell: a = 6.859(8) Å, b = 8.279(7) Å, c = 21.57(2) Å, α = 84.4(1)°, β = 85.6(2)°, γ = 68.59(5)° (M(20) = 10). The transition is spontaneously reversible, and the compound cooled to room temperature returns to its original crystalline form. After 100 °C the decomposition of the material continues with a series of unresolved steps (Figures S and S, ).

4 also shows a weight loss around 100 °C which is due to the loss of the two water molecules (calcd 6.92%, found 6.05%), yielding 4a. This phase is stable up to 300 °C, when decomposition of the organic part occurs (Figure S, ).

5 shows a weight loss around 100 °C due to the loss of two water molecules (calcd 6.92%, found 6.75%). Also this compound changes color from light blue to purple when heated, but the phase formed after the loss of water molecules is not as crystalline as the starting material; if the sample is cooled, it turns back to its initial color, but the PXRD pattern is different from those of both the initial material and the heated one, indicating that the transition is not reversible and permanent modifications in the structure are caused by the loss of the water molecules. The material is stable up to 300 °C, when decomposition of the organic part occurs (Figure S and S, ).

Following the evidence of non-negligible exchange interactions between Cu centers obtained by EPR spectroscopy, the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of the four samples was also investigated. At room temperature χT is 0.43, 0.43, 0.42, and 0.45 cm3 K mol–1 for 3, 4, 4a, and 5, respectively. The values are those expected for independent copper­(II) ions and agree well with the average g values obtained from EPR spectra.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior

 3 shows a first step of weight loss of 12.95%, occurring around 100 °C, which can be assigned to the loss of the three water molecules (calcd 14.15%). The PXRD pattern of this high-temperature phase was indexed with the following triclinic unit cell: a = 6.859(8) Å, b = 8.279(7) Å, c = 21.57(2) Å, α = 84.4(1)°, β = 85.6(2)°, γ = 68.59(5)° (M(20) = 10). The transition is spontaneously reversible, and the compound cooled to room temperature returns to its original crystalline form. After 100 °C the decomposition of the material continues with a series of unresolved steps (Figures S and S, ).

 4 also shows a weight loss around 100 °C which is due to the loss of the two water molecules (calcd 6.92%, found 6.05%), yielding 4a. This phase is stable up to 300 °C, when decomposition of the organic part occurs (Figure S, ).

 5 shows a weight loss around 100 °C due to the loss of two water molecules (calcd 6.92%, found 6.75%). Also this compound changes color from light blue to purple when heated, but the phase formed after the loss of water molecules is not as crystalline as the starting material; if the sample is cooled, it turns back to its initial color, but the PXRD pattern is different from those of both the initial material and the heated one, indicating that the transition is not reversible and permanent modifications in the structure are caused by the loss of the water molecules. The material is stable up to 300 °C, when decomposition of the organic part occurs (Figure S and S, ).

Following the evidence of non-negligible exchange interactions between Cu centers obtained by EPR spectroscopy, the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of the four samples was also investigated. At room temperature χT is 0.43, 0.43, 0.42, and 0.45 cm3 K mol-1 for 3, 4, 4a, and 5, respectively. The values are those expected for independent copper(II) ions and agree well with the average g values obtained from EPR spectra.
